quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: One of the top things I always hear about DoorDash from an executive standpoint when we do the internal survey is it's a 'no politics, no asshole' culture. If you really enjoy an interview, except for maybe something on the culture side, give the direct feedback and see how people engage.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: Six months later, he told me that one of the reasons why he joined DoorDash was that we were going to blackball him potentially from joining just because of his attitude, because his perspective is life's too short to work with people you don't really enjoy, and a lot of people pay lip service.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: If you want to achieve a 10x outcome, hiring someone that's an expert in the field, it's maybe unlikely you're going to achieve that 10x outcome, because they're likely to do things the way things have always been done. You might achieve incremental benefits, but the odds of completely reinventing the system is much lower.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: People talk a lot about hiring people better than you are. People don't talk a lot about what you do when you hire those people. If you really care about the company and your long-term brand as an individual, you realize what you want to do when you find the person that's better than you is you want to slowly get out of the way.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: One thing I found super effective is I try to ask the other side to make the opposing case. I say, 'Tell me the three best reasons why we should actually focus on growth here.' That generates instant empathy for the other side. And sometimes, they'll even persuade themselves as they're talking.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: If you create a space where you require constructive feedback, it's a lot easier to give feedback. One of the top things I hear from managers, especially new managers, they don't like giving constructive feedback. They want to be positive. They want to be liked. So requiring it is a nice way to create space for that dialogue.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: You have to thank them for it. And you have to action it. That's one thing I've found that can be really demotivating for folks. A lot of these companies have pulse surveys, they put the results on the screen, and 'We're going to work on it,' and that's the end of it. You need to come back and say, 'Here are the three things we did to action it.'

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: Tough times make companies. You're going to find out who the mercenaries are on the team, people that are there for the mission versus they're there because they think this is going to be a quick road to riches. It forces discipline. It's a good thing to focus on unit economics.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: People actually like crises at DoorDash. There's singularity of focus. You know what the job is. You know you're going to get whatever resources the company has when you're focused on the main thing. Talented folks really like that resourcing and singularity of focus about what the main thing is.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: Tony understands that by pushing a roadmap up, even by a week, if you can continuously push up what you ship by a week, you're going to end up lapping competitors who are just one week behind because you're going to start the next thing a week sooner, and you're getting that compounding return. And it grows and grows and grows.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: I remember our IPO day. The second it was over, we had our weekly business review, and there were tough questions being asked. There was not champagne being passed around. It reminds me of the saying, 'Somewhere, someone out there is practicing, and when you meet them, they will beat you.' It's important to stay hungry.

quotes.speaker: Keith Yandell
quotes.text: We should have gone out and tested this at one hotel with just some hacky operations and seen what the uptick was. I have two or three other examples where I learned I should have just gone out and stood out front with a promo code, and handed it out, and seen if that changed customer behavior, before going and asking for the product resources.

takeaways: Generalists can drive 10x outcomes that specialists miss - experts tend to do things the way they've always been done, while outsiders reinvent systems from first principles.
Force empathy in decision-making by asking each side to argue the opposing case - people will sometimes persuade themselves and always gain respect for the other perspective.
Create mandatory constructive feedback loops in one-on-ones and then visibly action the feedback - talking about valuing feedback without following through destroys trust.
Tough times are a feature, not a bug - they reveal who's truly mission-driven, force unit economics discipline, and create a singularity of focus that talented people crave.
Compound velocity wins markets - pushing a roadmap up by even one week repeatedly creates an exponential advantage over competitors who are always one step behind.

contrarian_candidates.why: Directly challenges the common hiring practice of seeking domain experts - argues that generalists are more likely to produce breakthrough 10x results
Counterintuitive claim that employees actually enjoy crises because of the clarity and focus they bring - challenges the assumption that stability equals satisfaction
